log.input: # Velocity Selector with Blocking Plate## Description of Physical Motion  The velocity selector is designed to filter charged particles with specific velocities. It consists of two parallel charged plates that create a uniform downward electric field and a magnetic field perpendicular to the plane of motion (into the screen). Positively charged particles entering the device from the left with horizontal velocity \(v\) experience a downward electric force and an upward magnetic force. When these forces are balanced, resulting in zero net force, the particle travels at a constant velocity in a straight line.  In this version (Program 20-2), an additional blocking plate with a small aperture is added at the exit. Only particles moving in a straight line with specific velocities pass through the aperture. This addition allows further filtering by selectively controlling the particles that can exit the velocity selector. The velocity of these particles can be adjusted by modifying the strengths of the electric and magnetic fields.  ### Key Simulation Features (Program 20-2)- Builds upon Program 20-1 by adding a blocking plate at the exit to filter particles.- Visualizes the electric field, magnetic field, parallel charged plates, blocking plate, and particle trajectories.- The particle stops moving if it collides with the charged plates or the blocking plate.  ## Conclusion  The addition of a blocking plate enhances the velocity selector's functionality by allowing only particles with specific velocities to pass through. The simulation is an excellent tool for visualizing and understanding the interactions of charged particles with electric and magnetic fields, as well as their filtering mechanisms.
log.output:
from vpython import *

scene = canvas(title="Velocity Selector with Blocking Plate", width=800, height=600)

# Constants
q = 1.6e-19  # charge of particle (C)
m = 1e-26    # mass of particle (kg)
v = 1e6      # initial velocity of particle (m/s)
B = 0.1      # magnetic field strength (T)
E = 100      # electric field strength (N/C)
L = 0.2      # length of plates (m)
d = 0.02     # separation between plates (m)
aperture_size = 0.02  # size of aperture in blocking plate

# Objects
charged_plate1 = box(pos=vector(-L/2-d/2, 0, 0), size=vector(0.01, 0.1, 0.1), color=color.blue)
charged_plate2 = box(pos=vector(L/2+d/2, 0, 0), size=vector(0.01, 0.1, 0.1), color=color.blue)
blocking_plate = box(pos=vector(L/2+d/2, 0, 0), size=vector(0.01, 0.1, aperture_size), color=color.red)
particle = sphere(pos=vector(-L/2-d, 0, 0), radius=0.005, color=color.yellow, v=vector(v, 0, 0), a=vector(0, 0, 0))

# Electric field arrow
E_arrow = arrow(pos=vector(0, 0, 0), axis=vector(0, -0.1, 0), color=color.green)

# Magnetic field arrow
B_arrow = arrow(pos=vector(0, 0, 0), axis=vector(0, 0, -0.1), color=color.orange)

# Time evolution
dt = 1e-9
t = 0
while True:
    rate(100000)
    
    # Update particle position
    particle.pos = particle.pos + particle.v*dt
    
    # Calculate forces
    F_e = q * E
    F_b = q * vector(0, particle.v.x*B, 0)
    
    # Calculate acceleration
    a = (F_e + F_b) / m
    
    # Update particle velocity
    particle.v = particle.v + a*dt
    
    # Check for collisions with plates and blocking plate
    if (abs(particle.pos.x) >= L/2+d/2 or (abs(particle.pos.x - (L/2+d/2)) <= aperture_size and abs(particle.pos.y) > 0.05)):
        particle.v = vector(0, 0, 0)
    
    t += dt

charged_plate2 = box(pos=vector(L/2+d/2, 0, 0), size=vector(0.01, 0.1, 0.1), color=color.blue)

scene = canvas(title="Velocity Selector with Blocking Plate", width=800, height=600)

# Constants
q = 1.6e-19  # charge of particle (C)
m = 1e-26    # mass of particle (kg)
v = 1e6      # initial velocity of particle (m/s)
B = 0.1      # magnetic field strength (T)
E = 100      # electric field strength (N/C)
L = 0.2      # length of plates (m)
d = 0.02     # separation between plates (m)
aperture_size = 0.02  # size of aperture in blocking plate

# Objects
charged_plate1 = box(pos=vector(-L/2-d/2, 0, 0), size=vector(0.01, 0.1, 0.1), color=color.blue)
charged_plate2 = box(pos=vector(L/2+d/2, 0, 0), size=vector(0.01, 0.1, 0.1), color=color.blue)
blocking_plate = box(pos=vector(L/2+d/2, 0, 0), size=vector(0.01, 0.1, aperture_size), color=color.red)
particle = sphere(pos=vector(-L/2-d, 0, 0), radius=0.005, color=color.yellow, v=vector(v, 0, 0), a=vector(0, 0, 0))

# Electric field arrow
E_arrow = arrow(pos=vector(0, 0, 0), axis=vector(0, -0.1, 0), color=color.green)

# Magnetic field arrow
B_arrow = arrow(pos=vector(0, 0, 0), axis=vector(0, 0, -0.1), color=color.orange)

# Time evolution
dt = 1e-9
t = 0
while True:
    rate(100000)
    
    # Update particle position
    particle.pos = particle.pos + particle.v*dt
    
    # Calculate forces
    F_e = q * E
    F_b = q * vector(0, particle.v.x*B, 0)
    
    # Calculate acceleration
    a = (F_e + F_b) / m
    
    # Update particle velocity
    particle.v = particle.v + a*dt
    
    # Check for collisions with plates and blocking plate
    if (abs(particle.pos.x) >= L/2+d/2 or (abs(particle.pos.x - (L/2+d/2)) <= aperture_size and abs(particle.pos.y) > 0.05)):
        particle.v = vector(0, 0, 0)
    
    t += dt
